title: Are there commonly accepted words used to describe certain sounds? - Quora

response.answer_text: In US English (not exhaustive): whoosh: sound of something passing by quickly plop: sound of something falling into liquid hiss: sound of air escaping through a small puncture or of an animal making a similar warning sound blam: sound of one large object striking another boom or ka-boom: sound of an explosion pow or wham: a fist striking someone or something grr: sound of an animal or human snarling tsk: a hard-to-describe not-very-loud sound of disapproval made with a sucking motion of the mouth vroom: sound of a motor being raced fizz: sound of liquid effervescence arf or woof: sound of a dog barking meow: a cat’s typical vocalization mew: a kitten’s soft vocalization baa: vocalization by a sheep or goat moo: a cow’s vocalization clink: small pieces of metal or glass striking together clank: larger pieces of metal or glass striking together

I can’t tell from your question if you are fishing for a particular word to cover the phenomena (onomatopoeia), or if you asking if the onomatopoeic terms we use in one language are commonly found in others in similar form. If you mean the later, generally no. For instance, as I mentioned in another thread on a similar topic, in ancient Egyptian, the word for “cat” was miu, which imitated the sound a cat makes. That is fairly close to the English meow. On the other hand, what’s the sound a dog makes onomatopoeically? Bow-wow? Ruff-ruff-ruff? Woof woof? In English, we might arbitrarily transliterate that sound three different ways, but other languages like Chinese might use the onomatopoeia “goû goû” instead. We use the onomatopoeia bang bang! to denote gunshots in English, but in French it is pan pan!
Every speech sound (in every language) has a name used by linguists (language scholars). For example, the “b” sound is called a voiced bilabial plosive. For more info, check out Phonetics.
